Buddhist Rulers of Sindh

The Rai dynasty was an important dynasty of Sindh (present-day Pakistan), which ruled in the period just before the arrival of Islam. They were patrons of Buddhism. Their capital was Aror. The boundaries of their empire extended to Makran in the west, Kashmir in the north, Rajasthan in the east, and Gujarat in the south.

тЪФя╕П
Political Significance

Rai Sahasi and Rai Sahiras were the prominent rulers of this dynasty. They faced the threats of the Persian Sasanian Empire. This dynasty was an interesting example of the coexistence of Buddhist and Hindu cultures in Sindh.

ЁЯУЙ
Deception and End

The dynasty ended with a political conspiracy. During the illness of the last king, Rai Sahasi II, his Brahman minister 'Chach' conspired with Queen Suhandi and seized power. After the king's death, Chach married the queen and founded the Brahman dynasty.
